 Just 'google it' using search terms "public schools" and "vouchers". You will get plenty of propaganda.
 
 The supporters of vouchers come in different flavors. Some claim that vouchers give "school choice" while others use it to send their kids to religious schools. In reality, vouchers resemble more like a pyramid scheme than any actual school reform. It is a scam.
 
 In Maryland, there was a failed attempt at a voucher system that would provided parents more than 5,000 dollars per child, varies per county. The amount is based on 75% of the per pupil spending in public schools. In Anne Arundel county, that would have been around 5500 dollars or so voucher per child.
 
 The average household in Anne Arundel county earns $60,000 per year. The average two-income household pays around $4000 in taxes towards education (the rest of the taxes goes to roads, fire departments, etc.) The average household pays this amount no matter how many kids it has (from zero all the way up to infinity).
 
 So, if you were in Anne Arundel county, own a home, and have four kids, you were to expect to get $22,000 in vouchers towards their education even though you only contributed $4000 in taxes for education. That's a net profit of $18,000. With vouchers, this $60,000 a year household is earning an equivalent of a $67,000 income tax-free (or roughly $100,000 income before taxes). With four kids, it is like getting a 66% raise. And the money for this raise comes from other taxpayers (singles, married couples with no children, and parents who chose to continue sending their kids to public schools).
 
 The voucher supporters are allowed to get away with this scam by using the per pupil spending of public schools as a substitute for the actual amount a household pays in taxes for public school education.

The primary reason the NEA is against vouchers is that it takes money out of the public school system. But this money is coming from parents who choose not to avail themselves of the public educational system.
 
 Parents who send their children to private / parochial schools (and a majority of public school teachers, politicians and celebrities do this) are actually paying TWO tuitions; one for the school their children actually attend, and one to the public schools.
 
 The public schools love this because they don't have to provide a seat for these students. However, it is an injustice to ask people to pay for something they do not use.
 
 The two most popular arguments AGAINST vouchers are that the government is supporting a religious institution (it isn't, the money goes to the parents, and they choose where to send their children), and that everyone benefits from a well-educated citizenry (true, but irrelevant).
 
 A just solution might be for parents to receive a tax credit for the period of time their children are actually of school age. After they graduate, the parents resume supporting their local public schools.
